12.text: As a little girl, I always imagined

15.text: I would one day run away.

17.text: From the age of six on,

19.text: I kept a packed bag with some clothes

21.text: and cans of food tucked away

22.text: in the back of a closet.

24.text: There was a deep restlessness in me,

27.text: a primal fear that I would fall prey

30.text: to a life of routine and boredom.

32.text: And so, many of my early memories involved

35.text:
intricate daydreams where
I would walk across borders,

40.text: and meet all kinds of strange people

42.text: living unconventional lives on the road.

45.text: Years have passed, but many of the adventures

48.text: I fantasized about as a child --

52.text: between worlds other than my own —

54.text: have become realities through my work

58.text: But no other experience has felt as true

63.text: as living amongst and documenting the lives

66.text: of fellow wanderers across the United States.

73.text: a different kind of American dream

83.text: the vagabond is a creature from the past.

86.text: The word "hobo" conjures up an old

90.text: of a weathered old man covered in coal,

92.text: legs dangling out of a boxcar,

94.text: but these photographs are in color,

103.text: seeing sides of America that no one else

110.text: travel the steel and asphalt arteries

115.text:
By day, they hop freight trains,
stick out their thumbs,

118.text: and ride the highways with anyone

123.text: By night, they sleep beneath the stars,

125.text: huddled together with their packs of dogs,

128.text: cats and pet rats between their bodies.

131.text: Some travelers take to the road by choice,

137.text:
and university degrees in exchange 
for a glimmer of adventure.

141.text: Others come from the underbelly of society,

144.text: never given a chance to mobilize upwards:

147.text: foster care dropouts, teenage runaways escaping

153.text: Where others see stories of privation

160.text: through the prism of liberation and freedom.

164.text: They'd rather live off of the excess

166.text: of what they view as a wasteful consumer society

169.text: than slave away at an unrealistic chance

174.text: They take advantage of the fact

178.text: up to 40 percent of all food ends up in the garbage

182.text: by scavenging for perfectly good produce

187.text: They sacrifice material comforts in exchange

190.text: for the space and the time to explore

194.text: to dream, to read, to work on music, art and writing.

199.text: But there are many aspects to this life

204.text: No one loses their inner demons

208.text: Addiction is real, the elements are real,

213.text: and anyone who has lived on the streets can attest

216.text: to the exhaustive list of laws

222.text: Who here knows that in many cities

223.text: across the United States it is now illegal

228.text: to wrap oneself in a blanket,

232.text: to sleep in your own car,

234.text: to offer food to a stranger?

238.text: I know about these laws because I've watched

241.text: were hauled off to jail or received citations

247.text: Many of you might be wondering why anyone

250.text: would choose a life like this,

251.text: under the thumb of discriminatory laws,

257.text: picking up seasonal jobs here and there.

260.text: The answer to such a question is as varied

263.text: as the people that take to the road,

265.text: but travelers often respond with a single word:

271.text: Until we live in a society where every human

274.text: is assured dignity in their labor

276.text: so that they can work to live well,

280.text: there will always be an element of those

282.text: who seek the open road as a means of escape,

285.text: of liberation and, of course, of rebellion.
